title: Edward Snowden has left airport
content:
Snowden had been at the Moscow airport for more than a month . Snowden gets Russian asylum
NSA leaker Edward Snowden has left the Moscow airport , entered Russia and been granted one-year temporary asylum , according to reports Thursday .
“ Over the past eight weeks we have seen the Obama administration show no respect for international or domestic law , but in the end the law is winning . I thank the Russian Federation for granting me asylum in accordance with its laws and international obligations , ” Snowden said upon receiving his certificate , according to WikiLeaks .
WikiLeaks released a statement about his departure , saying the one-year asylum will allow Snowden to live and travel freely within Russia as he plans his next steps .
Snowden , who has been living in the transit area of the Moscow airport for 39 days , had been waiting on necessary paperwork to leave , which arrived Thursday .
“ I have just handed over to him papers from the Russian Immigration Service . They are what he needs to leave the transit zone , ” Snowden ’ s Russian legal representative Anatoly Kucherena told Interfax , according to RT.com , which also reported that he has been granted a one-year temporary asylum .
The Russian news site also reported that Snowden left the airport about 30 minutes before his refugee status was announced for an undisclosed location , which will remain secret .
He left with WikiLeaks ’ s Sarah Harrison , WikiLeak said , who has been with him during the entirety of his stay in Russia and during his exit from Hong Kong .
“ Ms Harrison has remained with Mr. Snowden at all times to protect his safety and security , ” WikiLeaks said .
As news of Snowden ’ s release spread Thursday morning , lawmakers expressed their displeasure with Russia ’ s decision to grant Snowden temporary asylum .
The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said Russia ’ s move did damage to the country ’ s relationship with the United States and called for Russia to send Snowden home to face trial .
“ Edward Snowden is a fugitive who belongs in a United States courtroom , not a free man deserving of asylum in Russia , ” Sen. Robert Menendez ( D-N.J. ) said in a statement . “ Regardless of the fact that Russia is granting asylum for one year , this action is a setback to U.S.-Russia relations . Edward Snowden will potentially do great damage to U.S. national security interests and the information he is leaking could aid terrorists and others around the world who want to do real harm to our country . ”
Sen. Tom Coburn ( R-Okla. ) also said the development damages the U.S.-Russia relationship and Snowden ’ s stay in the country threatens U.S. security .
“ I think it probably hurts the relationship , you know he ’ s undoubtedly in my mind a traitor to our country and probably most of what he knows , the Russians already know . … It ’ s a gold mine for them , ” Coburn said Thursday morning on MSNBC ’ s “ Morning Joe . ”
Snowden had been staying at the Moscow airport for more than a month since leaving Hong Kong , where he initially fled to from the U.S. , for Russia in late June .
White House press secretary Jay Carney said the administration was “ extremely disappointed ” with the move on Thursday . The administration had repeatedly said Russia should extradite Snowden back to the U.S .
Just last week , the United States had continued its pressure on the Russian government to release Snowden , with Attorney General Eric Holder sending his Russian counterpart a letter assuring that Snowden would not face the death penalty in the U.S .
Snowden reportedly agreed to stop harming the U.S. by leaking information as a condition of asylum last month . However , The Guardian has continued to publish information initially provided to them by Snowden , including a report on Wednesday that the NSA has a tool to monitor Internet activity .

WikiLeaks released a statement about his departure, saying the one-year asylum will allow Snowden to live and travel freely within Russia as he plans his next steps.

Snowden, who has been living in the transit area of the Moscow airport for 39 days, had been waiting on necessary paperwork to leave, which arrived Thursday.

“I have just handed over to him papers from the Russian Immigration Service. They are what he needs to leave the transit zone,” Snowden’s Russian legal representative Anatoly Kucherena told Interfax, according to RT.com, which also reported that he has been granted a one-year temporary asylum.

( Also on POLITICO: Edward Snowden timeline of events)

The Russian news site also reported that Snowden left the airport about 30 minutes before his refugee status was announced for an undisclosed location, which will remain secret.

He left with WikiLeaks’s Sarah Harrison, WikiLeak said, who has been with him during the entirety of his stay in Russia and during his exit from Hong Kong.

“Ms Harrison has remained with Mr. Snowden at all times to protect his safety and security,” WikiLeaks said.

As news of Snowden’s release spread Thursday morning, lawmakers expressed their displeasure with Russia’s decision to grant Snowden temporary asylum.

( WATCH: Politicians sound off on Snowden)

The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said Russia’s move did damage to the country’s relationship with the United States and called for Russia to send Snowden home to face trial.

“Edward Snowden is a fugitive who belongs in a United States courtroom, not a free man deserving of asylum in Russia,” Sen. Robert Menendez (D-N.J.) said in a statement. “Regardless of the fact that Russia is granting asylum for one year, this action is a setback to U.S.-Russia relations. Edward Snowden will potentially do great damage to U.S. national security interests and the information he is leaking could aid terrorists and others around the world who want to do real harm to our country.”

Sen. Tom Coburn (R-Okla.) also said the development damages the U.S.-Russia relationship and Snowden’s stay in the country threatens U.S. security.

“I think it probably hurts the relationship, you know he’s undoubtedly in my mind a traitor to our country and probably most of what he knows, the Russians already know. … It’s a gold mine for them,” Coburn said Thursday morning on MSNBC’s “Morning Joe.”

Snowden had been staying at the Moscow airport for more than a month since leaving Hong Kong, where he initially fled to from the U.S., for Russia in late June.

White House press secretary Jay Carney said the administration was “extremely disappointed” with the move on Thursday. The administration had repeatedly said Russia should extradite Snowden back to the U.S.

Just last week, the United States had continued its pressure on the Russian government to release Snowden, with Attorney General Eric Holder sending his Russian counterpart a letter assuring that Snowden would not face the death penalty in the U.S.

Russia has repeatedly dodged U.S. requests to extradite Snowden.

Snowden reportedly agreed to stop harming the U.S. by leaking information as a condition of asylum last month. However, The Guardian has continued to publish information initially provided to them by Snowden, including a report on Wednesday that the NSA has a tool to monitor Internet activity.
